Re: "Betsy makes over $100,000 (as Paul postulated..."

Although a correction has not been forthcoming, for an "individual" (as described in his initial post) the subsidy cut-off is $46,000; for a married couple, the cut-off is $94,200. That is close to, but still less than, $100,000.

Link-followers learned that Bette was paying $552/mo for her old plan. And not to be a broken record, but in My Blue Heaven of Connecticut Bronze plans with a $12,600 deductible are offered; Covered CA has $10,000 Bronze deductibles. Are these junk plans under the ACA?

Bette's claims don't seem to hold up: you can go to the Washington exchange yourself, and clearly see that this lady's claim is baloney. Let's assume that the average Bronze plan is equivalent to her catastrophic plan; the most expensive option, assuming Betty and her spouse are both 64 years old with a household income of $100,000, is $976. Let's now assume that somehow, someway, two senior citizens managed to only pay $276 a month for insurance. Okay, now on to what Paul said:

"So this wasn’t sticker shock, at least as described. This was someone finding out that the ACA requires that you have a minimum level of insurance, and that minimalist plans are no longer allowed — and it was also Ms. Rodgers misrepresenting what had happened."

And that is so true. The bottom line is that Bette's claim is highly dubious. It is extraordinarily unlikely that two senior citizens (assuming a worse-case scenario) were only paying < $276 for coverage. If they were, it was a junk policy, plain and simple. More than likely, Betsy makes over $100,000 (as Paul postulated (has 10 employees working for her), and had a bare-bone plan (check), and did not actually sign up for a plan (check). Let's assume her premiums went up $500 instead of $700: let's just say that would make her an unfortunate minority of a minority.

Suggestion: Inequality isn't a product, it's part of the problem. Yes, population growth is part of it too, but not all. Consider, over the last 30 years we've been taking money from people that (mostly) spend it (lower and middle classes) and given it to people who largely invest it (the wealthy). Result: too much investment and too little consumption - i.e. secular stagnation.

I'm not saying it's scientifically proven (to quote from an earlier PK posting) but it does seem to make sense.

Economies function on demand.

When demand is suppressed, economies slow, stagnate and collapse.

A feudalized economy can't supply itself to good health.

Through the modern steroidization of capital flows, capital gains and tax avoidance, demand has been eviscerated as 'capital' moves like a hurricane from one port of call to another.

It all roots back to idle excess billions and trillions held by the global 1% looking to make it's customary killing.

Excess 1% wealth disproportionately stokes investment activity in market beauties of the month and then it engages in economic coitus interruptus, thereby unplugging the labor and demand economy as it rushes back to its one true love - the untaxed, obscured and offshored bank account.

1% wealth destroys demand by demanding and legislating low wage and low capital tax conditions, by being inherently more mobile than real human beings (i.e. labor) and by shrouding itself in unaccountable, shrouded corporate veils of secrecy.

Aside from the obvious solution - a modern French Revolution serving the 0.1%'s heads on breakfast platters - the more pragmatic solution is economic stabilizers like higher capital gains taxes to limit the violent sloshing of the 1%'s trillions in play money, a globally-based tax on the $20 or $30 trillion in offshored play money, a radical reform of the accepted larceny of 300:1 CEO:worker pay, and return to government-based Keynesian economics.

99% stimulus works much, much better than 1% stimulus.
Exactly, and the upside is, even if it fails to solve endemic problems of bubble and bust, we still get the infrastructure built.

Let's run an experiment. Borrow $1 trillion by issuing US bonds and fund a $1 trillion infrastructure program on traditional, basic infrastructure. No high speed trains, no alternative energy. Bridges, highways, urban transportation, waste water, clean water, broadband, public buildings, etc. Do matching funds with state and local projects funded with revenue bonds--projects that will have a future revenue stream that can repay capital investment.

Mr. Brooks is not necessarily encouraging us to swallow this tripe, but as a responsible, highly professional and moderate journalist, he is most likely drawing out his readership with their respective views in his writings today, and in conformity with his profession.

This is a badly scrambled column. The Whig Party deservedly vanished due to its failure to confront slavery in mid-19th century America, its economic growth mantle taken over by the then-new Republican Party. Of course, the Lincoln-era Republicans embraced the equality issue of the day: the need to outlaw slavery in many of imthe newly- settled territories of the American West.

Lincoln's support of federal expenditures for railroad expansion and homesteading would be repudiated by many of today's Republicans, as would his support of policies to limit inequality.

A tragedy of today's Republican Party is its abandonment of the ideals that made it great. It's a shame that Brooks is endorsing this drivel.

Brooks asks "is there a way" to do this that or the other as if the answers are somehow up in the ether. They are not. They are arrived at by hard economic – and therefore political – decisions.

To the party that he supports, every problem can be reduced to lowering taxes on its wealthy benefactors, and it goes out of its way to undermine any public spending remotely connected with the public good.

The way people support themselves now is hugely affected by extraordinarily rapid changes in technology, which are aggravated rather than moderated by economic, tax and trade policies. These latter must be overhauled to reverse the current upward redistribution of the national wealth and income. Brooks’ feel-good idea for President Obama to hire “Third Way” or “No Labels” style social entrepreneurs just won’t cut it. Instead, the President needs to belatedly channel his inner Roosevelt – both Teddy and Franklin – to push his party in a progressive direction and build a movement that will totally deprive the Republican Party of federal power preferably this year but certainly by 2016.

And may heaven preserve us from any more Simpson-Bowles commissions.

Finally, how will Brook's proposals simultaneously make life "maximally difficult for the next presidential candidates" and "a lot easier for the next swimmer in the race"?

Thank you for this impactful article and film. Both resonate deeply with me, as a daughter grappling with decision-making in the setting of my father's recent Alzheimer's diagnosis (in his early 60s). Currently in my last year of medical school, residency rank lists are due next month. I feel guilt at the thought of being away for 80 hour work weeks thus unable to help out at home; sad at the thought of missing what may be his remaining "good" years; and some fear of the future (and what it means for my father's condition) when I care for patients with Alzheimer's on clinical rotations (some of whom experienced intense personality changes, including becoming violent). I internally debate if I'm being incredibly selfish and "too Millenial" with persisting in chasing my dreams (and being in training for eons), and wonder if the opportunity costs will be worth it. Although my decision-making will yet require further deliberation, reading your article and watching your film have helped soothe some of my anxious thoughts. I do not know what the future may hold, but I am reassured that the love of family will persist. Your father sounds like he was a great human being; your tribute to him through your work displayed here has demonstrated that immensely well.
Beautiful. Touching. Thank you for making it and honoring your father.

My wife and I chose a third name when we got opposite-sex married. Having both grown up among a number of families with hyphenated names, we knew we didn't want to hyphenate, but we both wanted to have the same name as our potential kids, and neither of us was wild about taking the other's name. We chose my maternal grandmother's maiden name. So now we each have two last names, but our kids will have only one last name.
I don't miss my old name at all. It was great to take on a marker that when we got married, we became a family.
And congratulations to your son and his betrothed!

Isn't Krugman's description of "secular stagnation" quite concurrent with the expected outcome of a low-wage, high-inequality income regime? Workers not having a big enough share of the pie to generate vibrant consumer demand, and instead the money gets 'sequestered' at the top due to lower marginal propensities to consume.

Diminishing MPC seems to be the magic key to it all: an explanation that fits both the old Marxian overproduction model, and secular stagnation models.

comments.commentBody:
That's a bit too much emphasis on a situation that is more handy for headlines than evaluating economies. It's not a zero sum game, the 85 don't necessarily have that which would belong to someone else if it were not theirs.

First of all, voters control taxation, the super wealthy could be taxed to good effect if voters showed the will. Second of all, many of that lower 50% have so little wealth, or even negative wealth (in the case of anyone with debt,) that the 85 = 50% issue is a bit of a red herring. One American homeowner has more wealth than 100,000 villagers in Sudan etc.

Great point about the need for worldwide agreements and regulations; unfortunately, this will only be stimulated by a massive worldwide crisis. Perhaps what is happening in Turkey (and South Africa, Russia, Hungary, India, etc.) is the first sign of this...

Also, can you give a reference for 85 people owning more wealth than 1/2 of the world's population?

Nobody is saying that their shouldn't be winners, just that there shouldn't be losers.

The vast majority of current losers is made up of people who come from generations of people who have sacrificed to get us where we are without accumulating residual benefits from their collective contributions. Without them the economic and social platform on which winners stand would not exist.

There will always be slackers. It is just crass and inhumane to paint all people who do not succeed against the ebb and flow, that is, the whims of capitalism with the same brush. The simplistic evil represented by the use of that brush is representative of the shallow, self serving thinking of the modern Republican party.

Should we regulate the "quality of people" (Republicans do that by insisting that immigrants should be limited to the creme-de-la-creme of foreign talent)? Or should we strive to insure that we do everything we can to develop the talent that obviously exists in every human regardless of race, creed, or color? If we're going to wrap ourselves in the flag, why can't we tolerate ALL of the people that it represents?

It's certainly easy to 'grab somebody else's' stuff and go with the imported talent. Why do Republicans fight so hard to prevent the development of home grown talent? More money in their pockets, perhaps?

Eighty-five people own more wealth than fully 1/2 of the world's population. One of my long time European customers tells me that the rise of an elite super wealthy class is even greater in Europe than it is here. If correct, that means that Europe's middle-class in being hollowed out faster than ours.

Why should the incredibly wealthy risk a substantial portion of their estate on a gamble? Why take the risk? Just sit on the money and enjoy it.
Conversely, much of the remainder of the world does want to take a chance at wealth, but they don't have the money to invest. These two conditions combine to create secular stagnation. Insufficient funds get spent or invested.

Then we have the players that do want to gamble and make even more money. The financial industry, which profits greatly from these transactions, has designed casino like investment vehicles that can make their clients a lot of money until they collapse and there is a rush for the exits. Result? Repeated financial crises. Then the public get to pick up the tab.

The problem is severe global inequality saddled with a massive, unregulated global casino that benefits a tiny few and backed up by everyone else.

Only worldwide agreements and regulations can curtail these problems because there is only one economy. The brutal free market "me first" system seems to have reached its limit. Except for 85 people.

Correction, Mr. Spodick: Judge Scheindlin's order was not stayed on appeal. The panel of three federal appellate judges stayed Judge Scheindlin's order pending the outcome of an appeal, which appeal has not (and will not) take place. What's more, the panel did not accuse Judge Scheindlin of bias; rather, it said that her handling of the case COULD CREATE THE APPEARANCE OF BIAS. There's a difference. And that panel later clarified that it did NOT intend to imply that Judge Scheindlin had been guilty of any misconduct. As reported in this paper on November 13, 2013:

"The [panel;s original order had stated] that the judge's actions had compromised “the appearance of impartiality surrounding this litigation,” the panel had said.

The tone of the new opinion is completely different. It describes Judge Scheindlin as “a long-serving and distinguished jurist.” It notes that the earlier order had referred to the judicial code of conduct. “We now clarify that we did not intend to imply in our previous order that Judge Scheindlin engaged in misconduct,” the panel said.
